So we have seen about the fuzzy interference systems and their if then rules how we will write the if then rules in the fuzzy inference system and then we will we have also seen about the linguistic variables different types of linguistic variables how we will give it basically linguistic variables are the name which we will give to our inputs for basically mapping their inputs to the fuzzy input basically we are when we are converting our input to the fuzzy input or fuzzy fuzzy set basically when we are converting our crisp input to the fuzzy fuzzy set then we will use some membership function and for that membership functions we have to give some names. So that some names are called the linguistic variables it may for like if we will see the example of temperature then it may be its high low medium that type of names we will give to the temperature so that variables that names is that names is called the linguistic variables then we have seen the rule maps how we will map the rules to the output then we have seen the multiple types of rules like if we have any single condition it means when we are when we are having only one input then we will use the single condition like if A is X then B is Y that type of condition we have seen for the single and descendants and for all the multiple and for also for the multiple inputs in which like for example if we have two inputs temperature and humidity then if temperature is if temperature is low and humidity is low then fan speed should be high that types of rules we will decide we will write in the rule base. Now and we have also seen in the previous class about the T norms and S norms T norms is basically the AND operation and it means when we are combining the fuzzy inputs in the rules then we will use that that T norms whether we are combining the rules with the help of AND operation or T norms or where or otherwise we are combining with the help of OR operation that is S norms and different types of T norms we have seen like first one is minimum method product method and that two methods are there for the T norms and for the S norms we have again two methods that is maximum method and the probabilistic methods we have also seen with the help of example also we have seen in the previous class and that one is that we have seen about the firing stand basically it determines how our how strongly a rule is activated if multiples multiple rules are there in our rule base then which rule is how much activated how strongly it is activating on the output for aggregating of the outputs.
